column4: I know how to create startup scripts. But how do I make a startup script run last out of all the startup scrips...If that makes sense?
And or how do I make one run first. So the first thing init calls upon is the script in question
it probably depends on init system used
10.04 sooo system v
not systemd
initdaemon I guess right? Not systemd
in sysv style initscripts it was by numbers that prefixed name of symlink to initscript
00-99, put bigger number to start later, smaller to start sooner
well if I look in rc2.d for instance I see a few with the number 99 appended to their symlinks
that what your speaking about?
in sysv usually there are initscripts in /etc/rc.d/init.d/ and /etc/rc.d/rc#.d runlevel dirs with simlinks to those initscripts. 87_initscript will be run before 88_initscript
mmk thanks

so I just simply change the number? That wont screw aything up? Also to my understanding in ubuntu (for some reason) our run level 2 3 etc. all are multiuser with networking. So would I change the number for each script in each directory rc2.d rc3.d etc...?

to complete review of sysv initsript style there is also defined default runlevel in /etc/inittab, scripts in runlevel dirs are run with start or stop param depending if link name is prefixed with S or K (short for start or kill). and often there is also rc.local script, that usually is run after everything else, and might contain some commands/scripts to run in addition to those simlinked scripts
as to your last question, yes, simply rename that link (or script) with increased number for it to be run later after scripts with lesser numbers

just when changing number think that particular service might depend on other things run before it, so you shouldn't for example decrease number that much, when some dependant stuff hasn't been launched yet
nope no inittab here. And rc.local just executes whatever run level im in
ok good point
But this still does not answer if I should change the number for all run levels ubuntu calls multiuser + networking
Church- nevermind I guess all I have to worry about is the symlinks in rc2.d right?
set for runlevel you are booting to default
ok thanks again
